page.title: 01HIGH FELLS WEST OF ALSTON
page.content: The windswept North Pennines, snow covered for up to three months of the year, run north to south through the block, with Grey Nag (656m) the highest peak. The hills are heather covered above 550m, with eroded peat stacks forming flattened summit areas. The only shelter being stone dykes dividing the old commons into allotments of several hundred acres. There are no inhabited buildings. the land is rough grazed by sheep and some cattle. Woldgill Burn at the south and Knar Burn at the northwest form deep rocky valleys in which rowan and hawthorn form the only tall vegetation, with bracken areas in the cloughs. The country boundary through the south, seperating Northumberland and Cumbria is marked by boundary stones, of which Tom Smith's stone, an inscribed monument, is the, most
